data.title: Isn't there something schizophrenic about Marie magdeleine Roussin and Marie
data.meta_description: Just to make it clear neither Lemire or Lemyre or Lemyre_dit_Marsolais are that common names in Qu√©bec   ...  milicia captain ?  Does it makes sense ?
data.text:
From the Cambridge dictionary: Schizophrenic: "havingqualitiesorattitudesthat are different from each other and that do notworkwell together:

Decorated in a somewhat schizophrenic Moroccan/Asian theme, the hotel's rooms seem slightly dated.

There's something a little schizophrenic about the menu.

Despite dictionary definitions, which document how the word has been used in the past, the trouble with continuing this usage is that it perpetuates the idea that schizophrenia has something to do with "split personality". That is not correct, and the false concept can be harmful to an understanding of sufferers of the mental illness. It is more respectful and kinder to avoid using the adjective in this way. See also Wiktionary, which says

The informal use of this word (confusing the condition with multiple personality disorder) is discouraged to avoid stigmatization and misunderstanding of the disorder.
